title: PM urges Israeli action over accused child sex offender
text:
"The Australian Government will be unswerving in seeking justice in this matter."

Ms Leifer, 52, faces 74 counts of sexual assault over claims she abused at least eight students while principal of the ultra-orthodox Adass Israel School between 2001 and 2008.

She fled to Israel in 2008 before she could be charged and since 2014 fought extradition requests. with 60 court hearings on the matter.

Prosecutors claim she is faking mental illness to avoid extradition, with a judge setting a December deadline for further psychiatric reports on whether she is fit to stand trial.

Mr Morrison praised the courage of sisters Dassi Erlich and Nicole Meyer following his meeting with them.

"We acknowledge how deeply traumatic and painful it must be for those having to revisit the hurts of the past, and we acknowledge the immense bravery of the victims in this case, and all similar cases," he said.

Ms Erlich said the victims had faced an "extremely long battle for justice" and wanted Canberra to do more to bring it to an end.

"Enough is enough. We don't want platitudes, we want action," she said.

"This has taken a tremendous toll on both of our lives. I am travelling back and forth not seeing any results, the frustration of knowing at some point that she might get bail. It's just had an emotional toll on our lives."

Liberal MP Dave Sharma, who as ambassador to Israel first raised the case with officials in Tel Aviv, warned ties could be damaged without a speedy resolution.

"We have a good and productive relationship with Israel, but this is increasingly becoming an irritant, it's increasingly becoming a focal point in the relationship," he said.
description: Scott Morrison suggests a protracted extradition battle risks hurting ties between Australia and Israel.
